text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6Moo English
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…
speaker: Alice

text: And I'm Neil. Alice, if you've got two pounds, I've forgot my wallet and I need a coffee.
I've only got these pennies.
Sorry, I always use my bank card in the cafeteria.
You use a card to buy coffee?
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, it's a tap and go card, so it's quick.
You don't enter your pin number and everyone in the coffee queue uses them, except you.
And today's show is about how we pay for things.
Well, I pay for things with money!
speaker: Neil

text: There are different kinds of money.
There are different kinds of money. You're behind the curve, digging around in your pockets for change, Neil. Do you still use cheques too?
speaker: Alice

text: Do you still use checks, too?
Yes, I do. Ches are very useful.
Now, being behind the curve means not keeping up with current trends.
So, help me keep up, Alice. What's a tap and go card?
I thought you were talking about your regular bank card.
Well, tap and go cards are regular bank cards, but with a built-in chip and antenna.
The card reader sends out a radio frequency,
and when you bring the card close to the reader, the antenna picks up the signal to make the payment.
Hmm, this antenna business doesn't sound secure.
An antenna is used for sending or receiving radio signals.
Doesn't it mean your personal data is flying around in the ether for everyone to steal?
In this context, ether means the air, where electronic communication happens,
and nothing's flying around Peter Pan.
At less than half a second per transaction, there's no time for anyone to steal your cash.
Now, why don't you answer today's quiz question?
Which man's face appears on a UK £10 note?
Is it a child's Darwin?
or c)   Albert Einstein
speaker: ether

text: None of them – it's the Queen.
speaker: Neil

text: No, Neil. The Queen is on one side, but on the other side of each note is an important historical figure.
speaker: Alice

text: Oh, really? I've never noticed.
Okay, I'll go for B, Isaac Newton. He's a historical figure.
Hmm, well, so are Darwin and Einstein.
And coins and banknotes will be historical soon,
but we'll find out if you're right later on.
I'm still concerned about tap and go. What if someone steals my card?
Each contactless payment is limited to a certain amount.
The UK's limit is £30.
After you've used your card a few times in a row, you have to enter your pin.
And if a thief does go on a spending spree with your card,
your bank covers you against fraud.
Whereas if someone steals your banknotes, that's your bad luck.
Okay, good points.
Fraud means getting money by cheating people.
And a spending spree is a short period of time where you do a lot of shopping.
Are you a big spender, Alice?
Not with my tap and go, Neil.
How about you in your checkbook?
No comment.
speaker: Neil

text: Moving on.
If getting your bankcard out seems like too much trouble,
there's now a solution with wearable tech.
That's clothing and accessories that include computer and electronic technologies.
Let's hear what Kenneth Cukia, a technology expert, has to say.
You can simply take any wireless card and the chip from it,
that your bank might issue you and you can put it into the coat.
And then when you want to make a payment, just simply wave your arm in front of the terminal
and leave with your latte.
This is intended for people who are incredibly lazy,
who don't want to take their card out of their wallet,
or use their phone or use their watch.
People are going to be making more purchases, more of the time,
particularly for small value goods.
What Kenneth Cukia said is very interesting.
That sounds tempting, but I'm still concerned about how safe this all is.
What if I wave my arm around and make a payment by mistake?
The chip has to get very close to the card reader to make a payment,
so that's not likely to happen.
Now, companies are creating new biometric technology,
which you might like, Neil, because it combines payment and security technology.
Let's hear more from the BBC reporter Kate Russell.
For those times when not even carrying a phone is convenient,
at the beach or a festival, for example,
the finger pay system reads the unique maps of veins under the surface of your finger.
The trick is remembering which finger you registered with.
This high-tech stuff reporter Kate Russell is talking about is amazing.
Someday soon we won't have to carry a wallet or a purse or anything.
The veins in our finger will authenticate payments
and prove the payments are ours.
I can't wait.
Sounds a bit too sci-fi for my liking.
Hmm. Sounds a bit too sci-fi for my liking. How about giving us the answer to today's quiz question?
speaker: Neil

text: All right, then.
I asked which man's face appears on a UK £10 note?
Is it a child's Darwin,
b)   Isaac Newton
speaker: ether

text: or c, Albert Einstein?
And I said b) Isaac Newton.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, and you were wrong, Neil.
It was that other famous person, a, child's Darwin.
Isaac Newton was on the old £1 note, which is no longer used.
And Einstein was German, not British,
so he wouldn't appear on a UK bank note anyway.
Ah, well, they look similar, I think.
Well they look similar, I think. Can you tell us today's words once again, Alice?
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, of course I can. They are:
speaker: Alice

text: They are.
behind the curve
speaker: Alice

text: Tap and go.
antenna
speaker: Alice

text: ether
speaker: Alice

text: fraud
speaker: Alice

text: spending spree
speaker: Alice

text: wearable tech
speaker: Alice

text: authenticate
speaker: Alice

text: Well, that's the end of this edition of 6 Minute English.
Get ahead of the curve and join us again soon.
Meanwhile, visit our website,
BBCLearningEnglish.com,
where you'll find guides to grammar,
exercises, videos, and articles to read and improve your English.
Goodbye.
Bye.
speaker: Both

text: 6 Minute English from the BBC.
